repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Second East Java Urban
            Development Project, Bali Urban Infrastructure Project and
            Municipal Innovations Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second East Java Urban Development
            Project had a moderately satisfactory outcome and modest
            institutional development impact. The Bali Urban
            Infrastructure Project also had a moderately satisfactory
            outcome but its institutional development impact is
            substantial. The Municipal Innovations Project had a
            satisfactory outcome with modest institutional development
            impact. All three projects have unlikely sustainability. The
            performances of the Bank and the Borrower for all three
            projects were satisfactory.  Experience with the three
            projects suggests the following lessons: 1) Local
            governments should continue to build upon their demonstrated
            capacity to improve infrastructure delivery, but need to be
            more responsive to urban development needs expressed through
            local community participation. 2) A cross-sector framework,
            such as the Integrated Urban Infrastructure Development
            Program (IUIDP), can work well for local governments,
            provided the investment resources within it are sufficiently
            concentrated to adequately address needs in all included
            sectors. 3) All stakeholders, including local governments
            themselves, need to agree and clearly understand the purpose
            behind local innovations - be it to increase efficiency, to
            increase client-responsiveness. 4) The Bank should ensure
            that local governments are always included as partners, as
            it continues to emphasize improving their performance in
            service delivery. 5) Monitoring and Evaluation systems need
            to be designed and implemented to track outcomes related to
            project objectives, as well as the inputs and outputs of
            project activities that will help achieve these outcomes.

6761609.trustfund:
TF032754-ASIA REGION - METROPOLITAN
            ENVIRONMENT IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM,TF020952-SWISS GRANT TO WSP (EXPENSE A/C
            AS OF 12/31/97),TF029708-PHRD-BALI URBAN INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECT,TF030546-ITALIAN CTF - FY04 - EAP /ENERGY/TRANSPORTATION/WATER/IT,TF032099-ASIA;PACIFIC REGION -
            SUSTAINABLE BANKING WITH POOR,TF036787-INDONESIA - BALI URBAN
            INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECT,TF036788-INDONESIA - BALI URBAN
            INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECT,TF036789-INDONESIA - BALI URBAN
            INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECT,TF037052-INDONESIA - BALI URBAN INFRASTRUCTURE

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is substantial; Bank
            performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory. The project was a complex multi-sectoral urban
            infrastructure project, with special emphasis on PSP and
            cultural heritage, which expanded the decentralization
            envelope in Indonesia. High quality at entry, strong client
            commitment (especially at provincial and local levels), and
            dedicated supervision from a field based Bank team enabled
            the project to be implemented in a satisfactory manner,
            despite the multi-layered crisis that affected Indonesia
            from late 1997. The principal lessons concern handling the
            PSP in water supply as a separate project; making the CHC
            component more focused  on a limited number of activities
            and making financing by the Bank and the Borrower more
            effective; the efficacy of having strong leadership
            commitment and field-based supervision; tackling the problem
            of governance by making pioneering efforts made to benchmark
            costs, and improve transparency; and lastly, focusing the
            technical assistance component.

5083055.trustfund:
TF030546-ITALIAN CTF - FY04 - EAP /ENERGY/TRANSPORTATION/WATER/IT,TF036787-INDONESIA - BALI URBAN
            INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECT,TF036788-INDONESIA - BALI URBAN
            INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECT,TF036789-INDONESIA - BALI URBAN
            INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECT,TF032099-ASIA;PACIFIC REGION -
            SUSTAINABLE BANKING WITH POOR,TF037052-INDONESIA - BALI URBAN INFRASTRUCTURE,TF029708-PHRD-BALI URBAN INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECT,TF020952-SWISS GRANT TO WSP (EXPENSE A/C
            AS OF 12/31/97)

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Bali Urban
            Infrastructure Project are to make sustainable improvements
            in infrastructure services so as to meet basic needs in all
            important urban centers; and to meet the needs of growing
            urbanization in South Bali, as a result of tourism and other
            economic activities. Project component 1 consists of
            investing in the following subsectors: water supply, urban
            roads and traffic management, drainage and flood control,
            solid waste management, sanitation, neighborhood and market
            improvement programs, terminals and parking areas,
            incremental operations and maintenance for new and existing
            infrastructure, and detailed engineering design and
            construction supervision. Component 2 facilitates private
            sector participation in urban infrastructure services,
            particularly in water supply and solid waste, by offering
            technical assistance. Component 3, cultural heritage
            conservation, consists of five elements: (1) improving the
            Besakih complex neighborhood; (2) pilot conservation
            activities; (3) establishing a historic place inventory; (4)
            strengthening conservation capacities; and (5) producing
            signs in Indonesian and in other languages at heritage
            sites. Component 4 consists of technical assistance and training.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Bali Urban Infrastructure
            Program Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This Environmental Assessment deals with
            the Bali Urban Infrastructure Program (BUIP), which consists
            of urban physical infrastructure projects and services in
            the sub-sectors of water supply, urban roads, human waste
            water sanitation, solid waste management, market
            infrastructure improvement, village improvement and urban
            drainage and flood control. Possible positive environmental
            impacts from the project include: improved public health,
            hygiene, and safety; decreased road noise; and improved
            traffic patterns. Possible negative impacts and their
            mitigation measures include: a) water demand increase
            combined with an irrigation conflict, reduced groundwater
            level, runoff possibilities, and increased waste water
            amount - mitigated by reduced water speed, prompt
            replantation, infiltration ditches or settlement basins,
            careful water source and intake location selection,
            underground water transport piping placed parallel to roads,
            and sludge disposal at final site to avoid river
            contamination; b) soil erosion and pollution - mitigated by
            replanting and separate collection of clippings from dry
            waste; c) resettlement of populace - mitigated by a
            resettlement plan; d) noise and disturbance - mitigated by
            locating markets away from densely populated areas and sound
            barrier construction; e) reduced safety in rural areas;
            mitigated by provision of safe crossings, signaling, and
            speed limits; f) air quality, pollution and increased odor -
            mitigated by use of vegetation to filter dust, seal dirt
            access roads, use of closed sanitation treatment process,
            closed garbage vans, and dump coverage, centralized
            incineration and green zone creation; g) interference with
            local drainage pattern and ground water; mitigated by
            special attention to material and methods of sewers and
            septic tanks construction, systematic inspections; selection
            of dump sites above ground water level and covering dumps to
            prevent rainwater infiltration; and h) flora and fauna
            damage- mitigated by minimizing road cross section,
            construction of animal crossings, and speed limits or fencing.
